Introduction

Asbestos was extensively used as a building material in the past. It was used for a variety of purposes and was ideal for fireproofing and insulation. Any building built before 2000 (houses, factories, offices, schools, hospitals etc.) could contain asbestos. Asbestos materials in good condition are safe unless asbestos fibres become airborne, which happens when materials are damaged.

The presence of Asbestos Containing Materials (ACM's) does not itself constitute a danger, however, ACM's become hazardous when disturbed or damaged and must be treated accordingly. Activities that give rise to airborne dust, e.g. abrasion, breaking, sawing, cutting, drilling or machining ACM's are most likely to present risks.

The Trust has produced this policy in order to comply with the Control of Asbestos Regulations (CAR) 2012 and understands its duty to manage asbestos in nondomestic premises (Regulation 4 of CAR 2012).

The objective is to keep exposure and risks to damaging asbestos or from exposure to asbestos to a minimum whilst managing the asbestos containing materials (ACMs) within any of the organisations' properties or premises. This will be achieved by controlling all building and maintenance works and IT Infrastructure and dealing with asbestos which is known or is found to be situated in the premises of the Trust.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Take the necessary steps in locating materials in premises likely to contain Asbestos and to check their condition
Implement all reasonable and practicable steps to secure the health, safety and welfare of all persons who may be exposed to asbestos. This applies to all staff, contractors, patients and visitors.
Identify roles and responsibilities for the management of asbestos

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Health and Safety Committee
To ensure that this procedure is regularly reviewed, updated where necessary and approve this document.
To address any shortfall highlighted in the internal audit and review process
Duty Holder – Chief Executive Officer (CEO)

The Chief Executive Officer has the overall responsibility for Health & Safety within Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust and is accountable for the management of Asbestos whilst they are in the position of CEO, undertaking work on behalf of the Trust. The CEO is also responsible for:
Delegating the duties of this policy to the Appointed Person
Ensuring the Appointed Person demonstrates independence, impartiality and integrity
Ensuring the Appointed Person holds the correct accreditation to allow them to competently carry out the duties of this policy
Ensuring the Appointed Person is given the time and resources required to maintain the asbestos register
Authorising the Appointed Person to report asbestos incidents on behalf of the Board of Directors to the HSE.

The Senior Director of Estates and Facilities is the nominated Director with a responsibility for Health and Safety and will act on behalf of the Chief Executive in overseeing how the policy is put into practice and meeting the aims set. The Senior Director of Estates and Facilities is responsible for seeking sufficient resources to be made available, via the Investment Group Meeting, to the Estates Dept. with the aim of ensuring that the duties outlined in this policy are carried out. In the event that sufficient resources are not available, prioritisation of allocation of expenditure will be agreed with the Investment Group.
Appointed Person is responsible for:
Custodian of the asbestos register
Ensuring that the register is kept valid and up to date as far as is practicable
Appointing a Licensed Contractor to carry out re-inspections
Preparing F2508 for escalation of asbestos incidents to the Duty Holder
Sending approved F2508 to the HSE
Auditing and inspecting of asbestos removal works
Giving competent advice to those requiring information relating to asbestos works
Holding a valid BOHS P405 accreditation
Advise the Occupational Health Department in writing if a staff member has been exposed to asbestos.
Deputy Appointed Person is responsible for:
Supporting as required for the Appointed Person
Carrying out Appointed Persons duties when absent
Holding a valid BOHS P405 accreditation
Project Managers are responsible for:
Ensuring compliance with this and other related Policies, the requirement of current Health and Safety legislation and where appropriate, CDM Regulations.

Liaising with the Appointed Person to ensure that contractors and consultants have access to the Asbestos Register, who in turn are expected to satisfy themselves, prior to commencement of any work on Trust property, that it is safe to carry out their work.

Ensure room codes are provided to contractors and consultants for all rooms/areas that the contractor/consultant will be carrying out their work or surveys. The provision of room/area codes will enable the process of checking/accessing the asbestos register to be speeded up.
Contractors and Consultants are responsible for:

Accessing the Asbestos Register. It is the contractor's responsibility to ensure that the asbestos register is consulted prior to starting any work that may involve the disturbance of asbestos containing materials (ACM) on Trust premises. Permits to work will not be issued without confirmation that this has taken place.
Trust Employees All employees must:
Fulfil their legal duty under the Health and Safety at Work etc. Act1974.
Be aware of Management of Health and Safety at Work regulations (MHSW) 1999.
Co-operate with the Trust so far as is necessary in the implementation of this policy and procedure.
Consult the asbestos register prior to any work on the fabric of the building and seek for permit to work before such work commences.
Report unsafe conditions and unsafe act to their line manager and complete an electronic incident form as appropriate.
Ensure that safe systems of work, training and advice are followed at all times;
Surveys and sampling

Management survey: the continued surveying of known and presumed ACM's and associated sampling (where applicable) is to ensure the continued safety of patients, staff, contractors, visitors and the general public, by having a full and recorded understanding and consequent confirmation of all known ACM's.
All future surveys will be undertaken in accordance with guidance issued by the Health and Safety Executive i.e. HSG 264 Asbestos: The Survey Guide.

Only organisations able to provide and demonstrate evidence of compliance with ISO17025 (Organisation Sampling and for analysing ACM's) will be appointed to inspect, take and analyse samples on behalf of the Trust.

This type of survey aims to ensure that nobody is hammed by the continuing presence of ACM in the premises or equipment. It will ensure the ACMs remain in good condition and that nobody disturbs it accidentally.
The Survey must locate ACMs that could be damaged or disturbed by normal activities, by foreseeable maintenance, or by installing new equipment.

It involves minor intrusion and minor asbestos disturbance to make a Materials Assessment. This shows the ability of ACM, if disturbed, to release fibres into the air and will act as a guide in prioritising any remedial work. This will be achieved by creating;

Refurbishment and demolition surveys will be carried out prior to any major building refurbishment works involving disturbance of the building fabric or when demolition works are planned. For minor works e.g. drilling holes, the asbestos register will be checked, if no ACM's have been identified, the person who will be asbestos awareness trained should carry out their own assessments and proceed.
The survey must locate and identify all ACM before any structural work begins at a stated location or on stated equipment at the premises.
It involves destructive inspection and asbestos disturbance. The area surveyed must be vacated and certified 'fit for reoccupation' after the survey.
The surveyor will be provided with the site layout, building plans, building specifications or architect's drawings, and any history of asbestos work.
The surveyor must be shown site hazards, including means of safe access to heights.

The survey reports should state the location, presence and extent of asbestos- containing materials and debris. It does not assess the asbestos condition but the surveyor should mention any that is in a dangerous state.

The report should state where the surveyor or sampler did not survey or sample. You should presume that areas that the surveyor has not accessed do contain asbestos. Returned samples will refer to the ACM type or ‘no asbestos detected in sample' (NADIS)
On the receipt of information gained through any surveys and / or samples carried out, the Appointed Person will update the Asbestos Register accordingly to ensure its validity.
Labelling of ACM's

All ACM's will be labelled where practical to do so by the Licensed Contractor or the Appointed Person. In back of house areas namely; plant rooms, boiler houses, riser cupboards etc. the standard asbestos label will be used (shown in Fig 1 below). For front of house areas namely; in public areas, on wards etc. the label as shown in Fig 2 will be used.

Asbestos register
Southend: The Asbestos Register has been produced on the basis of data derived from Management Surveys that have been undertaken across Southend Hospital premises.

The Register contains references to confirmed and presumed ACM's. A copy is located within the Southend Hospital Estates and Facilities Department with the Appointed Person, or in their absence the Deputy Appointed Person. Access is available for reference at all times upon request.

The site plans identifying the location of ACM's will be updated as necessary by the Appointed Person or Licensed Contractor who is carrying out re-inspections or removals. Copies of these plans accompany the Asbestos Register.

After consultation with Essex Fire and Rescue Service it has been agreed that a copy of all Southend Hospital site plans showing location of all ACM's and the Asbestos Register detailing types and conditions of ACM's will be held in the switchboard. This can be used in case of emergency.

Broomfield: The Asbestos Register has been produced using data taken from the Trust wide Management Surveys. Details of every ACM located (identified or presumed) will be contained within. The Asbestos Register is in table format (produced on Microsoft Excel) and contains all relevant headings to match the example given in HSG 264.

A ‘read only' copy of the asbestos register is held within the Estates Works Department along with the hard copy management reports. When dealing with Trust properties away from Broomfield Hospital, the Site Manager will hold a ‘read only' copy of the asbestos register. An electronic copy of the Asbestos Register is held by the Appointed Person
All Trust staff and contractors are to be afforded access to DocLocker a remote hosting site, (read and print only) managed by the Oakleaf Group.
Computer access to Doclocker is to be available at the Estates Offices lobby and the Main Reception at St. Peters. Otherwise access is available through the web.

Basildon: The Asbestos Register has been produced using data taken from the Trust wide Management Surveys. Details of every ACM located (identified or presumed) will be contained within. The Asbestos Register is in table format (produced on Microsoft Excel) and contains all relevant headings to match the example given in HSG 264.

A ‘read only' copy of the asbestos register is held within the Estates Works Department along with the hard copy management reports. When dealing with Trust properties away from Basildon Hospital, the Site Manager will hold a ‘read only' copy of the asbestos register. An electronic copy of the Asbestos Register is held by the Appointed Person
Assessment of ACMs

When ACMs have been identified (or presumed), they are to be assessed by the surveyor in-line with HSG 264 as part of a Management Survey. This will provide a Materials Assessment Score that represents the ACMs ability to release asbestos fibres into the air. Each ACM is scored based on: type of material, type of asbestos, extent of damage, type of surface treatment.
ACMs will fall into the following categories depending on their assessment score: Potential to Release Fibre Score
High 10-12 Medium 7-9 Low 5-6 Very Low 2-4
Non asbestos materials are not scored.

The Appoint person will then work with the surveyors, estates staff and building/department managers to identify Priority Assessment Scores for each ACM. This will provide a score between 0-12 that shows the likelihood of normal building activities disturbing or damaging an ACM. Please see appendix 5 for a copy of the HSE material and priority scoring tool which can also be found at: http://www.hse.gov.uk/asbestos/assets/docs/materials-priority-scoring.pdf

When the two scores (Material and Priority) have been combined they produce the overall Risk Assessment score between 2-24 for that material in that location, this will be added to the Asbestos Register.

These scores are to be reviewed by competent people on a regular basis, and as a minimum, annually. The scores should also be reviewed before a change in occupation and likely activity occurs in areas containing ACMs or following any remedial works to an ACM.
Licenced contractors

Only specialist outside contractors will be engaged to undertake all work on Asbestos on Trust premises. The appointed contractor must hold a CURRENT LICENCE from the Health and Safety Executive Asbestos Licensing Unit.
All licensees are required to give minimum  days' notice of intention to work on or remove Asbestos. Work may commence within the  day notice period at the discretion of the Enforcing Authority.
Competent Asbestos removal contractors must:
a) Hold a current asbestos removal licence issued by the ‘Asbestos Licensing Unit' of the HSE.
b) Work to the requirements of HSG 247 (Asbestos; the licensed contractors guide).
c) Be registered under the Control of Pollution (Amendment) Act  and be certified by the act to be entered in the register which they maintain as a registered carrier of asbestos waste.
d) Show certification as a full Contracting member of the ARCA (Asbestos Removal Contractors Association) together with its Site Audit Accreditation Scheme.

Competent surveyors: UKAS accreditation for surveying companies is a well- established scheme. Accredited organisations can demonstrate that not only do they have competent surveyors but they are also working within a well-defined management system that provides confidence in the surveying procedures that are used. Competent surveyors must have:
a) The BOHS P402 ‘Building Surveys & Bulk Sampling' proficiency module as the minimum recognised qualification required to undertake Asbestos surveys.
b) Work to the requirements of HSG  (Asbestos: The Survey Guide) which recommends the use of UKAS accredited surveying companies/surveyors or ABICS certified surveyors.
c) Show independence, impartiality and integrity
Action Plan to prevent exposure to or release of, asbestos fibres
to air
The actions to be taken to prevent exposure to or release of, Asbestos fibres to air (to be overseen by the Appointed Person) may include a combination of the following;
Identification
Labelling
Enclosure / encapsulation
Management
Training
Controlled and monitored removal.
The communication of information on the presence or presumed location of ACM's will be given to employees, contractors and sub-contractors affected by the same.
This communication is implemented by the following;
Asbestos Awareness Training for relevant staff
Controlled access for project managers, contractors and sub-contractors under their employ
Provision of pre-construction information as required under the
Construction and Design Management Regulations (CDM).

If applicable instructions on restriction in areas containing or presumed to contain ACM's will be identified in the Asbestos Register and given to those likely to come into contact with the same by the Appointed Person.
Access to and disturbance within those areas known or presumed to contain ACM's will be controlled through the Permit to Work system as detailed in the Control of Contractors Policy.

All retained ACM's will be inspected on behalf of the Appointed Person, to ensure the integrity and state of repair of the material. These inspections shall be undertaken at intervals identified within the Management Plan by the Licensed Contractor under the supervision of the Appointed Person.
Inspections shall be recorded and included as part of the Asbestos Registers.

Air sampling will be undertaken as well as other predetermined procedures (see Appendices 1 and 3) by the Licensed Contractor when confirmed ACM's are identified as in a state of disrepair and during the course of any works.
Copies of all Analytical Monitoring Certification / Records will be forwarded to the Appointed Person for inclusion in the Asbestos Register.
Reactive and planned projects and maintenance and IT
Infrastructure works

When planning any works on Trust property, the presence of asbestos and the potential for the disturbance of asbestos is to be assessed before works commence. The same procedures must be adopted when using Trust staff or contractors in accordance with the Control of Contractors Policy
It is the responsibility of the Project Manager and/or person managing the works to:
ensure the Trust will not permit the use of new or existing ACMs in any new construction or installation
prevent ACMs being disturbed by general building works and activities
carry out risk assessments to assess if asbestos is likely to be disturbed by building works or activities
take reasonable steps to identify asbestos containing materials (ACMs).
presume materials to contain asbestos, unless there is evidence not to do so
Works involving asbestos disturbance and/ or removal
It is required that a communication is sent to staff in the area and to the Chair of Staffside to give them reassurance this will be given by the Trust Authorised Person.
In the case of exposure to staff member the Appointed Person must advise the Occupational Health Department in writing so health surveillance record can be updated.

All works involving the disturbance and / or removal of ACM's will be carried out in accordance with the detailed specification of works, which is to be produced by the Licensed Contractor, prior to any disturbance and in full liaison with the Trust Project Manager and / or Appointed Person. It will take into account all statutory / general requirements, together with the proposed future development of the site.

The Specification, Plan of Work, Method Statement Monitoring and Clearance Testing Strategy, must be agreed with the Trust Project Manager prior to implementation with, as previously stated, input and advice from the Appointed Person where appropriate.

The management and monitoring of all works involving the disturbance of ACM's, will be undertaken by the Licensed Contractor who will issue a detailed description of works which shall form part of the specification of works.
The Asbestos Removal Contractor and Asbestos Analyst will be appointed independently by the Trust Project Manager on behalf of the Trust.
During any such works, an approved monitoring strategy will be implemented to monitor and ensure effectiveness of all control measures being employed on site.

All areas subjected to disturbance and / or removal of ACM's will have Certificate of Re-Occupation issued prior to returning the same to normal usage. This will be approved by the Appointed Person on behalf of Trust. The Certificate of Re- Occupation will be kept on file by the Trust in the Estates & Facilities Department for reference for at least 40 years.

Works shall be classified as one of the following (determined from the description of works and the nature of the materials to be removed and further details pertaining to each classification are provided within Appendices 6 of this Policy):
Work with Asbestos Requiring a Licence
Work with Asbestos Not Requiring a Licence
Emergency procedures on disturbance of ACM or presumed ACM
The overall response to an ACM, or possible ACM, being accidentally disturbed is given in Appendix III of this policy, but is stated in more detail below
If any Trust staff or Contractors suspect that an ACM has been damaged, all work in the area shall cease immediately.
The incident shall be reported to the Estates Helpdesk via phone or a third party, who will inform the Authorised Person.
Access to the area will be prohibited (doors and windows to be locked, barriers erected, warning notices displayed) – ALL ventilation systems to be shut down and isolated.
Access to the area will be prohibited (doors and windows to be locked, barriers erected, warning notices displayed) – ALL ventilation systems to be shut down and isolated.
The Authorised Person shall check the relevant asbestos register to see if in fact the material was asbestos containing, and:

A) If the material is NOT asbestos then works can continue, but the Authorised Person shall investigate as to whether the relevant asbestos survey had been accessed by the required parties see why there was uncertainty.
B) If the material is found to be asbestos then take the appropriate response actions as below.
C) If it CANNOT be ascertained whether the material IS or IS NOT asbestos then it shall be presumed to be asbestos and the appointed laboratory or consultant shall be contacted.
No other persons are to interfere with the possible ACM without the Authorised Persons permission.
The Authorised Person is to arrange for samples of the material to be taken and analysed if an ACM is presumed. Air monitoring will also be undertaken for high risk ACMs that are damaged.
Any personnel who may have been contaminated by asbestos shall move as far away from the location of the incident as possible without contaminating other areas of the property.
Any person possibly contaminated with asbestos shall be issued with a FFP3 disposable mask and told to remove their clothing and place in asbestos waste bags for safe disposal.
Where the contamination of the operative is deemed to be significant, then a mobile decontamination unit may be brought to site to allow the operative to ‘fully' decontaminate with showering.
Any tools or equipment that the operative was using and which CANNOT be fully cleaned shall be disposed of as asbestos waste.

Where the material is known to contain or the sample is proved to contain asbestos, the Authorised Person shall arrange for the asbestos consultant to produce a specification for the cleaning and making safe of the area.

The Authorised Person will update the asbestos register and management information with details of the asbestos found and actions taken/to be taken. New Material and Priority Assessments will be produced.

An investigation into the incident will be carried out by Authorised Person to determine the cause. The report, findings and recommendations concerning the incident will be issued to the Head of Estates & Capital Projects for appropriate action.

Staff who may have been exposed should be offered health counselling from the Occupational Health Service. Records will be kept of all personnel who may have been exposed for a minimum of 40 years or until retirement age of the exposed person is reached. Upon which time it is recommended that the effected person obtain copies of these records for their own reference
Records
The Appointed person shall keep suitable records to demonstrate compliance with The Control of Asbestos Regulation 2012 including:

data.text: Training requirements

For those NHS staff that may come into contact with ACM's during their work activities they are required to attend asbestos awareness training every 3 years with refresher training for each year in between. This will ensure compliance with Regulation  of ‘The Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012 '.

Authorised Persons- The Trust will allow resources (time and costs) for all persons undertaking these roles, to complete the BOHS P405 ‘Management of asbestos in buildings  and  BOHS  P407  ‘Managing  asbestos  in  premises  the  Duty  Holder requirements', upon accepting the roles. This training is to be refreshed every 2 years or sooner if required.
Evidence  of  all  training  in  relation  to  asbestos  will  be  held  in  the  individual's personnel file and a copy retained by the Appointed Person.

For contractors who may come into contact with ACM's during their works at the Trust, valid certification of training in accordance with Regulation  of ‘The Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012' will be provided, which as a minimum must demonstrate they have undergone training within the last 3 years and a refresher training on an annual basis.

Appendix 1: Procedures in the event of an emergency affecting asbestos or presumed (ACM's)
ACTION IF ANY PERSON SUSPECTS THE PRESENCE OF ASBESTOS
Accidental disturbance or identification of damage to known or suspected ACM's will be reported immediately to the Appointed Person.
In addition, any person (Employee working at the Trust, Contractor or Sub-contractor) suspecting the presence of asbestos will:
STOP WORK
Note the location
Inform their immediate line manager
The line manager shall inform the Appointed Person
The Appointed Person shall inform the Trust Project Manager / Licensed Contractor as soon as practicable.

If the suspect material is, in the view of the Appointed Person or their representative, in poor condition, i.e. damaged and gives rise to airborne dust, the area containing the material will be controlled by:
Closing all doors and windows in the immediate vicinity
Advising people not to enter the area
A notice being fixed to all entrances in the area bearing the legend
‘NO ENTRY – CONTACT APPOINTED PERSON' in red on a white background and of prominent size and location. The notice will also include Appointed Person's contact details
Cordoning off external areas with barrier tape.
No person will interfere with the suspect material without prior consultation with the Appointed Person or Licensed Contractor

These procedures will be transmitted to employees working at the Trust, contractors and sub-contractors at both the tender stage of contracts, via Toolbox Talks and via communication of this policy on the Staffnet/ Hub.
On receiving notification of suspected asbestos, the Licensed Contractor will
Inspect the area as soon as possible
Arrange for a sample of the materials to be taken for analysis, if the Licensed Contractor considers it necessary
Give a written report of the investigation results of the investigation to the Appointed Person
Provide advice on any measures considered necessary to minimise the risk to health in the interim period.

Appendix 5: HSE material and priority scoring tool
Appendix 6: Work with asbestos containing materials (ACM's) requiring/ not requiring a licence
Requiring a licence

Only Licensed Contractors will be instructed to undertake licensable work on Asbestos. The Licensed Contractor must hold a CURRENT LICENCE from the Health and Safety Executive Asbestos Licensing Unit.

The majority of licences are issued for three years, but all new applicants are issued with twelve month licenses and are required to submit a suitable written Plan of Work to the enforcing authority for each contract. Companies, which change their name, are also required to take a twelve month licence and any existing licence they may hold will be cancelled. A few licences are still on issue for thirty months or three years, but no further such licences will be issued.

All Licensed Contractors are required to give minimum fourteen days notice of intention to work on or remove asbestos, other than that exempted by Regulation 3 (2) of the Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012. Work may commence within the fourteen day notice period at the discretion of the Enforcing Authority.

The HSE Licensing Scheme does not attempt to grade contractors by competence and there is no significance, in this respect, in the duration of licence held. HSE has found that competency depends more on local management of a contractor rather than the company itself. It is this reason that the Appointed Person / SUH Project Manager must satisfy themselves the written Plan of Works and Risk Assessment are adequate and also that essential precautions are being observed at all stages of the contract.

Licensed Contractors shall be appointed following assessments by the Appointed Person SUH Project Manager and any other value for money test in accordance with the SUH standing financial instruction (if appropriate).

Contractor Method Statements or written Plans of Work must detail how and where the work will be carried out. The written Plan of Work must be kept for at least two years after the work has been completed. In brief, the plan must include:
The nature and probably duration of the work
The location of where the work is to be carried out
The methods of handling ACM's
Details of the protection and decontamination equipment utilised by the contractors employees
The methods and controls for the protection of staff and others near to the work site
What segregation and signage will be utilised for the work area
Asbestos waste disposal
Not Requiring a Licence

Although not a requirement of the Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012, SUH will employ the services of a Licensed Contractor for all non-licensed works unless authorised in writing by the appointed person.
